description:
Should you just save money and buy the RTX 5070 Ti instead of the RTX 5080? In this video we answer that question by testing the latest games and technologies including DLSS 4, RT, Path Tracing and more!
Buy an RTX 5070 Ti: https://amzn.to/4khcjoU
Buy an RTX 5080: https://amzn.to/43aWV7F

Test system specs (ResizeBAR/SAM ON):
CPU: Ryzen 9800X3D https://amzn.to/40Nor9v
Cooler: Corsair H150i Elite https://amzn.to/3VaYqeZ
Mobo: ROG Strix X670E-a https://amzn.to/3F9DjEx
RAM: 32GB DDR5 6000 CL30: https://amzn.to/41XRtkM
SSD: Samsung 980 Pro https://amzn.to/3BfkKds
Case: Corsair iCUE 5000T RGB https://amzn.to/3OIaUsn
PSU: Corsair RM1000e (2023) https://amzn.to/3Z1XjS5
Monitor: LG 32GS95UE https://howl.me/cmk7W9HiD2F
Keyboard: Logitech G915 TKL (tactile) https://amzn.to/3U7FzA9
Mouse: Logitech G305 https://amzn.to/3gDyfPh

What equipment do I use to make my videos?

Camera: Sony a6100 https://amzn.to/3wmDtR9
Camera Lens: Sigma 16mm f/1.4 https://amzn.to/36i0t9t
Camera Capture Card: Elgato CamLink 4K  ‎https://amzn.to/3AEAPcH
PC Capture Card: https://amzn.to/3jwBjxF
Mic: My actual mic (AT 3035) is out of production but this is a similar mic (AT 2020) https://amzn.to/3jS6LEB
Portable Mic attached to camera: Rode Video Micro https://amzn.to/3yrT0R4
Audio Interface: Focusrite Scarlett 2i2 3rd Gen: https://amzn.to/3wjhlad
Greenscreen: Emart Collapsable https://amzn.to/3AGjQXx
Lights: Neewar Dimmable USB LED https://amzn.to/3yw4frD
RGB Strip Backlight on desk: https://amzn.to/2ZceAwC

Sponsor my channel monthly by clicking the "Join" button:
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC_ozUuauyPf1CgXztIWTOGA/join

Donate directly to the channel via PayPal:
https://www.paypal.com/donate?hosted_button_id=4G7D2YRVT9EDG

Disclaimer: I may earn money on qualifying purchases through affiliate links above.

comments.text: Why when lowering the resolution the cpu load goes up? Can someone explain to me in simple terms why it happens?
comments.author: @Cocker_Spaniel

comments.text: High resolution increases graphics card usage. Lower resolution increases cpu usage. Cpu determines how many fps you can get potentially. Gpu determines whether you can reach those frame rates. So if a game can get like 200fps at 1080p and like 80fps at 4k. It means that if you had a more powerful graphics card you could potentially get 200fps at 4k.
comments.author: @Brandon_Mishima

comments.text: Now say you get 200fps now with this new graphics card at 4k. You would think you can get 500fps maybe at 1080p. Turns out you only get 300. So what happened? This is called a cpu bottleneck. You most likely maxed out the frame rate the cpu can get. If you want higher frame rate you will need a better cpu.
comments.author: @Brandon_Mishima

comments.text:
@ I’m no PC expert, I’m just a mid 50’s guy that has built a new PC every decade or so since the age of 20 when his old PC has got too long on the tooth. So take what I say with a pinch of salt.

I’d say ‘yes’ you can do video editing an a laptop with a 4070Ti, but it might be a little frustrating. A laptops 4070Ti isn’t going to be as powerful as a desktops 4070Ti, a laptop is going to be thermally constrained vs a desktop & possibly power limited, especially when running on battery. But I’d say yes for simpler projects it would be okay, but not great.

My old desktop had a ~2008 mobo, an ASUS P6T which was an x58 socket, and it had a Xeon x5670 cpu & a 2017 1080Ti GPU. It could handle simple 10-15 min video editing, but it struggled to the point of failure if I tried doing anything too advanced like colour grading. Render times for a basic 13min video which was shot at 4k and rendered out to 1080p was around 40 minutes to an hour, but went to multiple hours when I added colour grading because I’d shot in s-log, and it often crashed during those renders or simply ‘failed’. 

One such ~13min vid which failed on the old PC after leaving it on all night rendering & in the morning it still said it wanted 15 hours, didn’t look like it had fully crashed, but it might have got stuck in a loop processing something, then new PC completed the same task in 5 mins. I would guess a laptop with a 4070Ti would probably complete the render but might take half an hour or more to do it. 

It’s not just render times, it’s also how smooth & fluid it is as you are scrubbing through your footage deciding on your edits. I’m using the full version of DaVinci Resolve and on my old PC I had to change the preview window to show quarter resolution (or use proxies) in order for it to scrub through footage smooth/fluid enough to decide edit in/out points and to generally assemble the edit, and even then on longer projects, it started to struggle. My old pc did have 64gb ram installed, but the mono was only able to address 48gb of it, and the OS & apps were running on an SSD, so a step up from a spinning disc hardrive. My data was on a NAS with 6 NVMe drives in a raid 6 array and connected to the PC via 10GBe ports either end, so the bottle neck was the PC processing ability, not because the data was on a NAS being accessed via a standard 1GBe Ethernet line. 

If you have not bought the laptop yet, I’d strongly suggest going for a laptop with a 50 series GPU & not a 40 series. Reason for this is because even the mobile 50 series have media encoders and the 50 series media encoders are superior to the 40 series as they handle h264 & h265 4.2.2 footage which the 40 series don’t. Many consumer cameras, like Sony Alpha’s, record in these formats and the 50 series has the media encoders which can hardware accelerate the handling of such footage. So if it were me, I’d be looking at laptops with 50 series GPU’s 70Ti, 80 or 5090.
comments.author: @TheLDunn1

I maybe looking for a laptop later this year myself, I was researching them at the end of last summer but decided to hold off. I need a laptop with a really good battery life, and at the time I was considering a laptop as a potential desktop replacement, so wanted really good performance too, but long battery life and high performance (on mains) don’t really come in the same single package, it’s usually an ‘either or’ situation, which resulted in me sorting out my desktop first. There were laptop advances on the horizon when I was looking that thought would be worth waiting for too, like the AMD Strix halo APU’s which promise arguably a better combination of battery life v performance. I don’t need high performance when I’m on battery, I just need long run times. I have two very different uses for a laptop that are polar extremes.

Also, WTF because I saw that the RTX 3060 has a 12 GB VRAM version and the RTX 3070 and 3070 Ti only has 8 GB?? What logic is that 😭😭😭😭
comments.author: @limnbakpoplolyihong8979

comments.text:
@limnbakpoplolyihong8979  Yes, but obviously I can't go and max out every setting on some games. I'd have to go with mid-high preset or set DLSS to Balanced or Auto.

Has to do with the memory controller. The 12gb version of the RTX 3060 uses a slower 192-bit memory interface (each chip provides 32-bit so 192/32=6gb). They could either go 6gb or 12gb and perhaps they thought 6gb is too low and no one would want to buy that so they went "screw it let's just go with 12gb". The 3070 uses 256-bit so it got 8gb (256/32=8).
